column1: Edinburg is part of the McAllen–Edinburg–Mission and Reynosa–McAllen metropolitan areas.

column2: John Closner
column5: Plutarco de la Viña and Dennis B. Chapin developed a new community at this site. The town square was located at the current crossroads of U.S. Highway 281 and State Highway 107. The town was named "Chapin" in honor of one of the developers. A local myth relates that Edinburg became the county seat of Hidalgo County in a dramatic
column6: nighttime covert operation in which the county records were removed from the previous county seat. However
column7: historical records show more practical reasons. The original Hidalgo County Courthouse in the city of Hidalgo was under frequent danger of flooding because of the town's proximity to the Rio Grande
column8: which sometimes encroached on the building. Additionally
column9: Texas law required that the courthouse be close to the geographic center of the county. When Dennis Chapin was involved in the shooting death of Oscar J. Rountree at the Dan Breen Saloon in San Antonio
column10: the community changed its name to "Edinburg" to honor John Young
column11: a prominent businessman who was born in Edinburgh
column12: Scotland. The town was officially named in 1911 and incorporated in 1919.

column1: Edinburg is located in south-central Hidalgo County at 26°18′15″N 98°9′50″W (26.304225
column2: -98.163751). It is bordered to the south by Pharr and to the southwest by McAllen
column3: the largest city in the county. U.S. Route 281 (Interstate 69C) runs through the east side of Edinburg. US 281 leads north 103 miles (166 km) to Alice and 229 miles (369 km) to San Antonio. Downtown McAllen is 10 miles (16 km) to the south and west.

column1: === University of Texas Rio Grande Valley ===

column2: officials announced the merger of the existing University of Texas-Pan American in Edinburg and the University of Texas at Brownsville into a regional institution. A year later
column4: University of Texas System officials decided to name the new institution the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley. UTRGV's creation garnered much media attention because of its expected economic
column5: social and health care impact on the region. UTRGV is unique in that it is the first time the UT System has merged existing campuses in such a way. UTRGV will also bring the first medical school to the Rio Grande Valley region. The first class of UTRGV students began courses in fall 2015.

column1: Edinburg is also the home of the Rio Grande Bible Institute located in the South Texas College District.
Almost all of the city is served by the Edinburg Consolidated Independent School District
column2: comprising four high schools
column5: and 20 elementary schools. A small portion is served by the McAllen Independent School District

column2: the South Texas Independent School District operates magnet schools that serve Edinburg. South Texas Business Education & Technology Academy (BETA) is in Edinburg. Students from Edinburg also have the chance to attend other South Texas ISD schools in Mercedes -South Texas High School for the Medical Professions and The Science Academy of South Texas.

column1: The Catholic Diocese of Brownsville operates St. Joseph Catholic School
column2: an elementary and middle school.

column1: The city of Edinburg operates the Dustin Michael Sekula Memorial Library.
Edinburg is home to the Museum of South Texas History
column2: formerly the Hidalgo County Historical Museum.

column1: As Edinburg is the county seat of Hidalgo County

column3: the District Courts and County Courts at Law of Hidalgo County

column5: the Hidalgo County Juvenile Probation Department
column6: the Hidalgo County Sheriff's Office and the offices of the County Judge
column9: County Auditor and Veterans Services. Hidalgo County Commissioner's Precinct Four represents Edinburg on the Hidalgo County County Commissioner's Court.

column1: This city was the home of the Edinburg Roadrunners

column5: UTRGV is the only major baseball team in Edinburg.

column2: the city of Edinburg and the Edinburg Economic Development Corporation announced plans for the construction of an events arena in which the NBA Development League Champions
column4: would be the anchor tenants. It opened in 2018.  The team also has its practice facility at the Edinburg Sports & Wellness Center. The City also opened a six-city-block stretch of green pedestrian walkway space known as the McIntyre Street Project in April 2014 expected to be the beginning of a proposed arts and restaurant district extending through the heart of Edinburg.Since 2016
column5: the city has been home to the Rio Grande Valley FC Toros soccer club in the USL Championship
column6: who play at H-E-B Park. The city is also home to the Rio Grande Valley FC Toros Academy
column7: the best youth soccer club in the area and a pioneer in youth development for the Rio Grande Valley. The Toros Academy plays in the MLS Next league against the best academies in the nation and provides fully-funded programs for U-15

column1: There are two major commercial airports near Edinburg: McAllen Miller International Airport (MFE) at McAllen
column2: 20 minutes from Edinburg and Valley International Airport
column4: 40 minutes from Edinburg. The South Texas International Airport at Edinburg (KEBG) is a public use airport owned and operated by the City of Edinburg.
